title: 2011–12 Czech First League
text:
The 2011–12 Czech First League, known as the <a href="Gambrinus%20%28beer%29">Gambrinus</a> liga for sponsorship reasons, was the 19th season of the <a href="Czech%20Republic">Czech Republic</a>'s top-tier <a href="Association%20football">football</a> league. It began on 29 July 2011 and was originally due to end on 26 May 2012, although due to the <a href="Czech%20Republic%20national%20football%20team">Czech Republic</a>'s qualification for <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202012">UEFA Euro 2012</a>, the end of the season was brought forward to 12 May 2012. <a href="FC%20Viktoria%20Plze%C5%88">Viktoria Plzeň</a> were the defending champions, having won their first Czech Republic championship <a href="2010%E2%80%9311%20Czech%20First%20League">the previous season</a>.
<a href="AC%20Sparta%20Prague">Sparta Prague</a> started the season with eight consecutive wins, the first such occurrence in league history. Sparta broke their own record when they won their ninth straight league match and opened up a 10-point lead at the top of the table.
The title was decided on the last day of the season, with <a href="FC%20Slovan%20Liberec">Liberec</a> hosting <a href="FC%20Viktoria%20Plze%C5%88">Viktoria Plzeň</a> in the knowledge that a win for either team would seal the title, with a draw being enough for Liberec to retain first place. In front of a sold-out stadium at <a href="Stadion%20u%20Nisy">Stadion u Nisy</a>, Liberec held the visitors to a goalless draw, winning the league for the third time since 2002.
Teams.
<a href="FK%20%C3%9Ast%C3%AD%20nad%20Labem">Ústí nad Labem</a> and <a href="FC%20Zbrojovka%20Brno">Zbrojovka Brno</a> were relegated to the 2011–12 <a href="Czech%202.%20Liga">Czech 2. Liga</a> after finishing last and second to last, respectively, in the <a href="2010%E2%80%9311%20Czech%20First%20League">2010–11 season</a>. Ústi nad Labem therefore immediately returned to the second tier, while Brno completed a nineteen-year tenure in the top flight.
The relegated terms were replaced by <a href="2010%E2%80%9311%20Czech%202.%20Liga">2010–11 2. Liga</a> champions <a href="FK%20Dukla%20Prague">Dukla Prague</a> and <a href="FK%20Viktoria%20%C5%BDi%C5%BEkov">Viktoria Žižkov</a>. Viktoria Žižkov returned after a two-year absence, while Dukla Prague made their debut in the league; however, the Dukla Prague name returned to the league after seventeen seasons, with a <a href="Dukla%20Prague">club of the same name</a> having played in the top Czech football division until then. The newly promoted clubs were granted licenses to play top-division football on 13 June 2011.
Viktoria Žižkov became the first team to be relegated on 5 May 2012 after <a href="FC%20Ban%C3%ADk%20Ostrava">Ostrava</a> beat <a href="1.%20FK%20P%C5%99%C3%ADbram">Příbram</a>.
